Quaternions and Attitude Representation

Hardik Parwana111Research Assistant, IIT Kanpur email: parwanahardik@gmail.com, Mangal Kothari222Assistant Professor, IIT Kanpur email: mangal@iitk.ac.in
Department of Aerospace Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, India

1 Attitude Representation

The attitude of a rigid body belongs to the configuration space known as Special Orthogonal group S​O​(3)𝑆𝑂3SO(3) and is represented in most general terms as 3×3333\times 3 rotation matrix. The space can, however, be parameterized in terms of fewer parameters. The advantages and disadvantages of some important representations used are summarized below:

  • •

    Rotation matrices: This is the most general form for representing attitude of a body, also called special orthogonal group S​O​(3)𝑆𝑂3SO(3) group, is the space of 3×3333\times 3 matrices satisfying some constraints. Since it uses nine numbers to represent three angular degrees of freedom, there are six independent constraints on the matrix elements. Each column(and row) is unit vector, which gives us 3 constraints and the columns (and rows) are orthogonal to each other, yielding another 3 constraints. The translation (∈R3absentsuperscript𝑅3\in R^{3}) and rotation together are represented as Special Euclidean group S​E​(3)𝑆𝐸3SE(3). The 6 constraints are larger compared to all other parameterizations mentioned below. They are therefore computationally more expensive than them. However, these have the advantage that they have no singularities or ambiguities such as double cover in attitude space in their representation as the rotation matrix is uniquely determined for a given configuration.

  • •

    Euler angles: These are more intuitive and easy to interpret physically. However, they suffer from singularity in mathematical formulations such as in Roll-Pitch-Yaw, also known as gimbal lock. At Pitch angle of 900superscript90090^{0}, it is unable to differentiate between Yaw and Roll degrees of freedom. There may also be a discontinuity when moving the angles in the parameter space, say, at ±πplus-or-minus𝜋\pm\pi. One of the Euler angles change suddenly in response to small change in rotation.

  • •

    Unit Quaternions: Owing to parametrization by 4 variables compared to 3 in Euler angles, these do not have singularity problem. Also, any rotation sequence can be represented by a continuous quaternion trajectory and do not suffer any discontinuity like Euler angles. These are also computationally more efficient than Euler angles since computation of sines and cosines is more expensive than simple operator on numbers. However, they possess the ambiguity of dual covering, i.e., the quaternions q𝑞q and −q𝑞-q represent the same quaternion. It is also easier to interpolate between rotations and to chain rigid transformations.

  • •

    Axis/angle representation: It parameterizes the rotation by a unit vector n→→𝑛\vec{n} and a rotation about it by angle θ𝜃\theta. Since unit vector has a norm constraint, three parameters are required for representation, 2 for unit vector and 1 for rotation angle. The representation is not unique and an additional rotation of 3600superscript3600360^{0} gives the same rotation matrix. However it has many advantages too. The representation is minimal and does not require any constraints on parameters such as unit modulus of quaternions used to represent rotations. It is easer to understand the pose (example a twist about y axis) and the derivatives of rotation matrix R with respect to rotation angle can easily be computed.

2 Problem with Euler Angles

Although Euler angles are widely used because of their minimalistic (3 parameters for 3 Degrees of Freedom) and intuitive physical representation, they exhibit a phenomenon known as Gimbal Lock which results in a singularity in the attitude representation. Note that the Euler angles are relative sequential rotations (See video on GuerrilaCG Youtube channel: Euler (gimbal lock) Explained: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zc8b2Jo7mno ). For example in a 123 rotation, a single roll angle will change the orientation of pitch and yaw axis but in case of a single pitch angle rotation, the roll axis remains intact while yaw axis changes its orientation with the pitch rotation. When the pitch is 900superscript90090^{0}, the roll and yaw axis becomes the same and system can rotate only about 2 axis in space at that particular instant. Therefore, when the axis of two out of the three gimbals are driven parallel to each other in a configuration, there is a loss of degree of freedom and the dimension of the attitude space reduces to 2. The gimbal is still free to move(there is no actual mechanical lock as the name suggests) however, in order to move along the third missing axis in this configuration, the body will have to move simultaneously along two gimbals axis and may exhibit unfamiliar motions when such a situation is encountered physically. There are many ways in which people deal with this problem while still using Euler angles however, that treatment is not a topic of these notes.

2.1 Mathematical Implication

Mathematically the formulation of attitude space in terms of Euler angles can cause a singularity and demand …. commands. Consider a rigid body with its angular velocity represented by the orthogonal vector [p​q​r]Tsuperscriptdelimited-[]𝑝𝑞𝑟𝑇[p\leavevmode\nobreak\ q\leavevmode\nobreak\ r]^{T} as per the convention. The Euler rates [ϕ˙​θ˙​ψ˙]Tsuperscriptdelimited-[]˙italic-ϕ˙𝜃˙𝜓𝑇[\dot{\phi}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \dot{\theta}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \dot{\psi}]^{T} are not orthogonal as they are defined in different frame of references and, for a 321 rotation, can be related to angular velocity as follows:

[pqr]=[ϕ˙00]+R​(ϕ)​[0θ˙0]+R​(ϕ)​R​(θ)​[00ψ˙]matrix𝑝𝑞𝑟matrix˙italic-ϕ00𝑅italic-ϕmatrix0˙𝜃0𝑅italic-ϕ𝑅𝜃matrix00˙𝜓\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}p\\ q\\ r\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\dot{\phi}\\ 0\\ 0\end{bmatrix}+R(\phi)\begin{bmatrix}0\\ \dot{\theta}\\ 0\end{bmatrix}+R(\phi)R(\theta)\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ \dot{\psi}\end{bmatrix} (1)
[pqr]=[10−sin⁡θ0cos⁡ϕsin⁡ϕ​cos⁡θ0−sin⁡ϕcos⁡ϕ​cos⁡θ]​[ϕ˙θ˙ψ˙]matrix𝑝𝑞𝑟matrix10𝜃0italic-ϕitalic-ϕ𝜃0italic-ϕitalic-ϕ𝜃matrix˙italic-ϕ˙𝜃˙𝜓\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}p\\ q\\ r\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}1&0&-\sin\theta\\ 0&\cos\phi&\sin\phi\cos\theta\\ 0&-\sin\phi&\cos\phi\cos\theta\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\dot{\phi}\\ \dot{\theta}\\ \dot{\psi}\end{bmatrix} (2)

The determinant of the above matrix becomes zero at θ=900𝜃superscript900\theta=90^{0} and there the dimension of the space reduces to 2. The matrix can be inverted to obtain Euler rates in terms of angular velocity as:

[ϕ˙θ˙ψ˙]=[1sin⁡ϕ​tan⁡θcos⁡ϕ​tan⁡θ0cos⁡ϕ−sin⁡ϕ0sin⁡ϕ​sec⁡θcos⁡ϕ​sec⁡θ]​[pqr]matrix˙italic-ϕ˙𝜃˙𝜓matrix1italic-ϕ𝜃italic-ϕ𝜃0italic-ϕitalic-ϕ0italic-ϕ𝜃italic-ϕ𝜃matrix𝑝𝑞𝑟\begin{bmatrix}\dot{\phi}\\ \dot{\theta}\\ \dot{\psi}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}1&\sin\phi\tan\theta&\cos\phi\tan\theta\\ 0&\cos\phi&-\sin\phi\\ 0&\sin\phi\sec\theta&\cos\phi\sec\theta\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}p\\ q\\ r\end{bmatrix} (3)

At the singularity point, the matrix elements are not defined as tan\tan and sec\sec terms go to ∞\infty.

3 Quaternions

Quaternions can be considered as 4 component extended complex number of the form

q=q0+q1​i+q2​j+q3​kp∘q≠q∘pp∘q∘r=(p∘q)∘r=p∘(q∘r)formulae-sequenceqsubscript𝑞0subscript𝑞1𝑖subscript𝑞2𝑗subscript𝑞3𝑘formulae-sequence𝑝𝑞𝑞𝑝𝑝𝑞𝑟𝑝𝑞𝑟𝑝𝑞𝑟\textbf{q}=q_{0}+q_{1}i+q_{2}j+q_{3}k\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ p\circ q\neq q\circ p\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ p\circ q\circ r=(p\circ q)\circ r=p\circ(q\circ r) (4)

where in q=(q0,q→)𝑞subscript𝑞0→𝑞q=(q_{0},\vec{q}), q0subscript𝑞0q_{0} is called the real part and q→=(q1​q2​q3)T→𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞3𝑇\vec{q}=(q_{1}\leavevmode\nobreak\ q_{2}\leavevmode\nobreak\ q_{3})^{T} is called the imaginary part of the quaternion. 4 Quaternion: Intuitive Representation

A unit quaternion (|q|=1𝑞1|q|=1) can be used to represent a rotation in space. This set of 4 dimensional vectors with unit modulus are said to belong to set S3superscript𝑆3S^{3}[4]. Since its modulus is one, q−1=q¯=q∗superscript𝑞1¯𝑞superscript𝑞q^{-1}=\bar{q}=q^{*}(q∗superscript𝑞q^{*} is also the notation for conjugate of quaternion which is more commonly used in case quaternion elements are complex numbers. Since rotation quaternions have real entries, q∗=q¯superscript𝑞¯𝑞q^{*}=\bar{q}). Henceforth, all the quaternions mentioned will be unit quaternions unless stated otherwise.

Euler’s Rotation Theorem
Any rotation or sequence of rotations of a rigid body or coordinate system about a fixed point is equivalent to a single rotation by a given angle θ about a fixed axis (called Euler axis) that runs through the fixed point.

Quaternions can be very easily correlated to the axis angle representation of attitude. Any attitude of a rigid body can be defined by stating an axis in 3D with unit vector n→→𝑛\vec{n}, and a rotation about that axis, θ𝜃\theta. A rotation quaternion can be represented in terms of these two as:

q=(c​o​s​(θ2),n→​sin⁡(θ2))𝑞𝑐𝑜𝑠𝜃2→𝑛𝜃2q=\left(cos\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right),\vec{n}\sin\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)\right) (21)

As verification, consider the well known rotation formula studied in dynamics course.

x→′=(1−cos(θ))(n→.x→)n→+cosθx→+sinθ(x→×n→)\vec{x}^{\prime}=(1-\cos(\theta))(\vec{n}.\vec{x})\vec{n}+\cos\theta\vec{x}+\sin\theta(\vec{x}\times\vec{n}) (22)

where θ𝜃\theta is the rotation about the axis of rotation n→→𝑛\vec{n}

Now consider the equation

x′=q¯∘x∘qx=(0,x→)q=(q0,q→)formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑥′¯𝑞𝑥𝑞formulae-sequence𝑥0→𝑥𝑞subscript𝑞0→𝑞x^{\prime}=\bar{q}\circ x\circ q\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ x=(0,\vec{x})\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ q=(q_{0},\vec{q}) (23)

Simplifying the above, we get

R​e​(x′)𝑅𝑒superscript𝑥′\displaystyle Re(x^{\prime}) =\displaystyle= (q→.x→)q0−q0(x→.q→)−(q→×x→)⋅q=0\displaystyle(\vec{q}.\vec{x})q_{0}-q_{0}(\vec{x}.\vec{q})-(\vec{q}\times\vec{x})\cdot q=0 (24)
I​m​(x′)𝐼𝑚superscript𝑥′\displaystyle Im(x^{\prime}) =\displaystyle= 2(q→.x→)q→+q02x→+2q0(x→×q→)−(q→.q→)x→\displaystyle 2(\vec{q}.\vec{x})\vec{q}+q_{0}^{2}\vec{x}+2q_{0}(\vec{x}\times\vec{q})-(\vec{q}.\vec{q})\vec{x} (25)

If we now choose q𝑞q as q=(cos⁡θ2,sin⁡θ2​n→)𝑞𝜃2𝜃2→𝑛q=(\cos\frac{\theta}{2},\sin\frac{\theta}{2}\vec{n}), |n|=1𝑛1|n|=1, then x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} becomes:

x′→=(1−cos(θ))(n→.x→)n→+cosθx→+sinθ(x→×n→)\vec{x^{\prime}}=(1-\cos(\theta))(\vec{n}.\vec{x})\vec{n}+\cos\theta\vec{x}+\sin\theta(\vec{x}\times\vec{n}) (26)

This is same as the known rotation formula.

4.1 Extension of complex numbers

It is well known that multiplying a complex numbers r1​ei​θ1subscript𝑟1superscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝜃1r_{1}e^{i\theta_{1}}(=r1​cos⁡θ1+i​r​sin⁡θ1subscript𝑟1subscript𝜃1𝑖𝑟subscript𝜃1r_{1}\cos\theta_{1}+ir\sin\theta_{1}) by r2​ei​θ2subscript𝑟2superscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝜃2r_{2}e^{i\theta_{2}} results in amplification of its magnitude by r2subscript𝑟2r_{2} times and change in orientation by an angle θ2subscript𝜃2\theta_{2} (product = r1​r2​ei​(θ1+θ2)subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2superscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2r_{1}r_{2}e^{i(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2})}). See Fig.1 for an example. Now if we were to multiply with a unit modulus complex number, i.e. r2=1subscript𝑟21r_{2}=1, then we can perform pure rotation. Quaternions can be seen just to be an extension of this mathematical construction and the constraint of unit modulus to higher dimension.

5 Quaternion Conventions

Quaternions are represented in many ways and have different interpretations. For example, one can consider rotating frames or rotating vectors or a left handed or right handed operations(Note that the usual vector cross product is based on right handed system, however it can also be defined in a left handed system). Two most commonly used notations are Hamilton and JPL conventions, both of which considers rotating frame[2]. The one used in these notes above and which will be used in subsequent theory is the Hamilton convention. Some differences between two are:

where L𝐿L stands for local frame and G𝐺G stands for global frame. Therefore given the sequence of operation q∘−∘q∗q\circ-\circ q^{*}, we go from local frame to global frame in Hamilton notation and vice versa in JPL when going from left hand side to right hand side in an equation.

6 Quaternion Derivatives

Quaternion derivatives are often used to represent angular velocity or to integrate the system dynamics. This section will state and derive some important relations which are very common in literature.

6.1 First Derivative

The quaternion rates are given in terms of angular velocity expressed in global frame (w=(0,w→)𝑤0→𝑤w=(0,\vec{w})) or body frame (w′=(0,w→′)superscript𝑤′0superscript→𝑤′w^{\prime}=(0,\vec{w}^{\prime})).

q˙˙𝑞\displaystyle\dot{q} =\displaystyle= 12​q∘w′12𝑞superscript𝑤′\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}q\circ w^{\prime} (27)
q˙˙𝑞\displaystyle\dot{q} =\displaystyle= 12​w∘q12𝑤𝑞\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}w\circ q (28)
w′superscript𝑤′\displaystyle w^{\prime} =\displaystyle= 2​q¯∘q˙2¯𝑞˙𝑞\displaystyle 2\bar{q}\circ\dot{q} (29)
w𝑤\displaystyle w =\displaystyle= 2​q˙∘q¯2˙𝑞¯𝑞\displaystyle 2\dot{q}\circ\bar{q} (30)

A simple derivation for the quaternion rate is done using the first principle[2].

q˙˙𝑞\displaystyle\dot{q} =\displaystyle= lim△​t→0q​(t+△​t)−q​(t)△​tsubscript→△𝑡0𝑞𝑡△𝑡𝑞𝑡△𝑡\displaystyle\lim\limits_{\triangle t\rightarrow 0}\frac{q(t+\triangle t)-q(t)}{\triangle t} (31)
=\displaystyle= lim△​t→0q∘△​qL−q​(t)△​tsubscript→△𝑡0𝑞△subscript𝑞𝐿𝑞𝑡△𝑡\displaystyle\lim\limits_{\triangle t\rightarrow 0}\frac{q\circ\triangle q_{L}-q(t)}{\triangle t} (32)
=\displaystyle= lim△​t→0q∘([1n→​△​θL/2]−[10])△​tsubscript→△𝑡0𝑞matrix1→𝑛△subscript𝜃𝐿2matrix10△𝑡\displaystyle\lim\limits_{\triangle t\rightarrow 0}\frac{q\circ(\begin{bmatrix}1\\ \vec{n}\triangle\theta_{L}/2\end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0\end{bmatrix})}{\triangle t} (33)
=\displaystyle= lim△​t→0q∘([0n→​△​θL/2])△​tsubscript→△𝑡0𝑞matrix0→𝑛△subscript𝜃𝐿2△𝑡\displaystyle\lim\limits_{\triangle t\rightarrow 0}\frac{q\circ(\begin{bmatrix}0\\ \vec{n}\triangle\theta_{L}/2\end{bmatrix})}{\triangle t} (34)

Note that in Hamilton notation, local disturbances or rotations(i.e., with respect to current configuration) are post-multiplied as done above since we move from local to global frames when going left. Thus, the change in angle △​θl/△​t△subscript𝜃𝑙△𝑡\triangle\theta_{l}/\triangle t represents the angular velocity in body frame. Similarly if one were to add global disturbances(i.e., with respect to glbal coordinate system and not the current body configuration), they would be pre-multiplied and not post-multiplied. This can be better understood by following example. Consider the following two sets of consecutive rotations:

  1. 1.

    Case a: Rotation about Z𝑍Z by 450superscript45045^{0}, then rotation about X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime}(new X𝑋X axis) by 900superscript90090^{0}

  2. 2.

    Case b: Rotation about Z𝑍Z by 450superscript45045^{0}. then rotation about X𝑋X(original X𝑋X axis) by 900superscript90090^{0}

Consider the vector [0 0 1]delimited-[]001[0\leavevmode\nobreak\ 0\leavevmode\nobreak\ 1] in the final frame of reference. We desire to obtain this vector in the original frame of reference. From Fig.2 it is clear that Case a should yield [12​−12​ 0]delimited-[]1212 0[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \frac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}\leavevmode\nobreak\ 0] as the answer and Case b should yield [0−1 0]delimited-[]010[0\leavevmode\nobreak\ -1\leavevmode\nobreak\ 0] as the answer.

Let us denote first rotation quaternion by q1superscript𝑞1q^{1} and the second by q2superscript𝑞2q^{2}. In the first case, since we are rotating with respect to local frame of reference, this local perturbation is post multiplied, i.e., qa=q1∘q2superscript𝑞𝑎superscript𝑞1superscript𝑞2q^{a}=q^{1}\circ q^{2}. Whereas, in the second case, we are rotating again with respect to global frame of reference, therefore we will be pre-multiplying, i.e., qb=q2∘q1superscript𝑞𝑏superscript𝑞2superscript𝑞1q^{b}=q^{2}\circ q^{1}.

Let x𝑥x denote the quaternion corresponding to position vector in global frame and x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} denote the quaternion corresponding to position vector in local frame. Another derivation for the derivative formula is as follows[1]:

x𝑥\displaystyle x =\displaystyle= q∘x′∘q¯𝑞superscript𝑥′¯𝑞\displaystyle q\circ x^{\prime}\circ\bar{q} (36)
x˙˙𝑥\displaystyle\dot{x} =\displaystyle= q˙∘q¯∘x∘q∘q¯+q∘q¯∘x∘q∘q¯˙˙𝑞¯𝑞𝑥𝑞¯𝑞𝑞¯𝑞𝑥𝑞˙¯𝑞\displaystyle\dot{q}\circ\bar{q}\circ x\circ q\circ\bar{q}+q\circ\bar{q}\circ x\circ q\circ\dot{\bar{q}} (37)
x˙˙𝑥\displaystyle\dot{x} =\displaystyle= q˙∘x′∘q¯+q∘x′∘x¯˙˙𝑞superscript𝑥′¯𝑞𝑞superscript𝑥′˙¯𝑥\displaystyle\dot{q}\circ x^{\prime}\circ\bar{q}+q\circ x^{\prime}\circ\dot{\bar{x}} (38)
=\displaystyle= q˙∘q¯∘x+x∘q∘q¯˙˙𝑞¯𝑞𝑥𝑥𝑞˙¯𝑞\displaystyle\dot{q}\circ\bar{q}\circ x+x\circ q\circ\dot{\bar{q}} (39)

Now from definition of quaternion product,

q˙∘q¯˙𝑞¯𝑞\displaystyle\dot{q}\circ\bar{q} =\displaystyle= (q˙0​q0+q→˙⋅q→,−q˙0​q→+q0​q→˙−q→˙×q→)subscript˙𝑞0subscript𝑞0⋅˙→𝑞→𝑞subscript˙𝑞0→𝑞subscript𝑞0˙→𝑞˙→𝑞→𝑞\displaystyle(\dot{q}_{0}q_{0}+\dot{\vec{q}}\cdot\vec{q},-\dot{q}_{0}\vec{q}+q_{0}\dot{\vec{q}}-\dot{\vec{q}}\times\vec{q}) (40)

where in last step scalar part becomes zero, which can be obtained by differentiating |q|2=1superscript𝑞21|q|^{2}=1, and the vector part is defined as v→→𝑣\vec{v} for convenience.

Therefore, we get

Now for pure rotation, x→˙=w→×x→˙→𝑥→𝑤→𝑥\dot{\vec{x}}=\vec{w}\times\vec{x} where w→→𝑤\vec{w} is the angular velocity and is perpendicular to x→→𝑥\vec{x}. Therefore, we have

⟹wabsent𝑤\displaystyle\implies w =\displaystyle= (0,w→)=(0,2​v→)=2​q˙∘q¯0→𝑤02→𝑣2˙𝑞¯𝑞\displaystyle(0,\vec{w})=(0,2\vec{v})=2\dot{q}\circ\bar{q} (45)

7 Rotation Matrix

The rotation matrix R which transforms x→′superscript→𝑥′\vec{x}^{\prime} to x→→𝑥\vec{x} can be written as[1]:

R=E​GT𝑅𝐸superscript𝐺𝑇R=EG^{T} (60)

The R matrix is obtained as:

R=[q02+q12−q22−q322​(q1​q2−q0​q3)2​(q0​q2+q1​q3)2∗(q1​q2+q0​q3)(q02−q12+q22−q32)2​(q2​q3−q0​q1)2​(q1​q3−q0​q2)2​(q0​q1+q2​q3)q02−q12−q22+q32]𝑅matrixsuperscriptsubscript𝑞02superscriptsubscript𝑞12superscriptsubscript𝑞22superscriptsubscript𝑞322subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞32subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞32subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞3superscriptsubscript𝑞02superscriptsubscript𝑞12superscriptsubscript𝑞22superscriptsubscript𝑞322subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞3subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞12subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞3subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞22subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞3superscriptsubscript𝑞02superscriptsubscript𝑞12superscriptsubscript𝑞22superscriptsubscript𝑞32R=\begin{bmatrix}q_{0}^{2}+q_{1}^{2}-q_{2}^{2}-q_{3}^{2}&2(q_{1}q_{2}-q_{0}q_{3})&2(q_{0}q_{2}+q_{1}q_{3})\\ 2*(q_{1}q_{2}+q_{0}q_{3})&(q_{0}^{2}-q_{1}^{2}+q_{2}^{2}-q_{3}^{2})&2(q_{2}q_{3}-q_{0}q_{1})\\ 2(q_{1}q_{3}-q_{0}q_{2})&2(q_{0}q_{1}+q_{2}q_{3})&q_{0}^{2}-q_{1}^{2}-q_{2}^{2}+q_{3}^{2}\end{bmatrix} (61)

This can easily be seen as: w→=2​E​q˙=2​E​(GT​w→′/2)=E​GT​w→′⟹R=E​GT→𝑤2𝐸˙𝑞2𝐸superscript𝐺𝑇superscript→𝑤′2𝐸superscript𝐺𝑇superscript→𝑤′𝑅𝐸superscript𝐺𝑇\vec{w}=2E\dot{q}=2E(G^{T}\vec{w}^{\prime}/2)=EG^{T}\vec{w}^{\prime}\implies R=EG^{T}.

The rotation matrix derivative can then easily be obtained as[1]

R˙˙𝑅\displaystyle\dot{R} =\displaystyle= R​Ω′𝑅superscriptΩ′\displaystyle R\Omega^{\prime} (62)
Ω′superscriptΩ′\displaystyle\Omega^{\prime} =\displaystyle= 2​G​G˙T2𝐺superscript˙𝐺𝑇\displaystyle 2G\dot{G}^{T} (63)

where Ω′superscriptΩ′\Omega^{\prime} is the skew symmetric matrix corresponding to the angular velocity vector.

8 Problems with Quaternions and other attitude representations

8.1 Quaternions

(q0,q→)=(−q0,−q→)subscript𝑞0→𝑞subscript𝑞0→𝑞(q_{0},\vec{q})=(-q_{0},-\vec{q})

Since there are two quaternions:

  • •

    Ambiguities in representing an attitude: The constraint of unit modulus of quaternions restrict the quaternions to a sphere of unit radius in 4 dimensions, known as the three-sphere which is the set of unit-vectors in R4superscript𝑅4R^{4}. This three sphere doublecovers the attitude configuration of the special orthogonal group, SO(3).

  • •

    Single physical attitude of a rigid body may yield two different control inputs, which causes inconsistency in the resulting control system. A specific choice between two quaternions generates discontinuity that makes the resulting control system sensitive to noise and disturbances.

8.2 General Representation

We first need to understand an important fact related to attitude stabilization. It has been proved mathematically[4] that there cannot exist a smooth controller on the configuration space (such as S​O​(3)𝑆𝑂3SO(3) or S3superscript𝑆3S^{3}) that is globally asymptotically stable.

Theorem: The geometry of attitude space precludes the existence of continuous time invariant control that achieves global asymptotic stability.

The proof of this theorem is a little involved with consideration of topological obstructions and configuration manifold which is out of scope of these notes. Details can be found in Reference [4]. Note that even the geometric controllers which work on S​O​(3)𝑆𝑂3SO(3) directly instead of any parameterizations have also been shown to be almost globally asymptotically stable, such as in [5], where a two dimensional manifold is excluded from the three dimensional S​O​(3)𝑆𝑂3SO(3) in the region of attraction. In case of quaternions or Euler angles it is easy to note that since q𝑞q and −q𝑞-q and 00 and 2​π2𝜋2\pi represent the same attitude, there exists more than one equilibrium point and thus one cannot even talk about global stability. One can filter the algorithm for these cases but then the controller becomes discontinuous (non-smooth) and hence the above theorem is not violated.

Unwinding Phenomenon: The body may rest arbitrarily close to the desired attitude yet rotate through large angles before coming to rest in the desired attitude[4].

Consider a body rotating about a single axis in a plane with angular velocity ω​(t)𝜔𝑡\omega(t) with angular position θ​(t)𝜃𝑡\theta(t). We can design a control torque u​(t)𝑢𝑡u(t) to stabilize the system dynamics as:

θ˙​(t)=ω​(t)˙𝜃𝑡𝜔𝑡\displaystyle\dot{\theta}(t)=\omega(t) (64)
ω˙​(t)=u​(t)˙𝜔𝑡𝑢𝑡\displaystyle\dot{\omega}(t)=u(t) (65)
u​(t)=−k​θ​(t)−c​ω​(t)𝑢𝑡𝑘𝜃𝑡𝑐𝜔𝑡\displaystyle u(t)=-k\theta(t)-c\omega(t) (66)
⟹θ¨​(t)+c​θ˙​(t)+k​θ​(t)=0absent¨𝜃𝑡𝑐˙𝜃𝑡𝑘𝜃𝑡0\displaystyle\implies\ddot{\theta}(t)+c\dot{\theta}(t)+k\theta(t)=0 (67)

It may seem that θ=0𝜃0\theta=0 is globally asymptotically stable point but values of θ𝜃\theta that differ by integral values of 2​π2𝜋2\pi represent the same point in configuration space and hence it is not well defined in the state space. If we start at θ=2​π−ϵ𝜃2𝜋italic-ϵ\theta=2\pi-\epsilon, then instead of going shorter way of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon anticlockwise, the controller will take it 2​π−ϵ2𝜋italic-ϵ2\pi-\epsilon clockwise.

9 Quaternion Error Dynamics

The quaternion error is defined as the relative rotation between the desired rotation and actual rotation. In order to better understand the inverse multiplication operation, we take example of rotation matrices. Suppose the rotation matrices corresponding to two consecutive relative rotations are R1subscript𝑅1R_{1} and R2subscript𝑅2R_{2}. The net rotation matrix is then given by R3=R2​R1subscript𝑅3subscript𝑅2subscript𝑅1R_{3}=R_{2}R_{1}. Now if R3subscript𝑅3R_{3} and R2subscript𝑅2R_{2} were to be given, then R1subscript𝑅1R_{1} can be found by multiplying both sides by inverse of R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}.

R3subscript𝑅3\displaystyle R_{3} =\displaystyle= R2​R1subscript𝑅2subscript𝑅1\displaystyle R_{2}R_{1} (68)
⟹R1absentsubscript𝑅1\displaystyle\implies R_{1} =\displaystyle= R2−1​R3superscriptsubscript𝑅21subscript𝑅3\displaystyle R_{2}^{-1}R_{3} (69)

Now suppose R3=Rsubscript𝑅3𝑅R_{3}=R takes us from body to global frame and R2=Rdsubscript𝑅2subscript𝑅𝑑R_{2}=R_{d} takes us from desired to global frame. Then R1=R~subscript𝑅1~𝑅R_{1}=\tilde{R}(error rotation matrix) takes us from body to desired frame. Hence the error rotation matrix can be found out by:

R~=Rd−1​R~𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑑1𝑅\tilde{R}=R_{d}^{-1}R (70)

The quaternions behave in a similar way to the rotation matrices. If the body attitude quaternion is q𝑞q and the desired body attitude is qdsubscript𝑞𝑑q_{d} then the the error quaternion is defined as

qe=qd−1∘qsubscript𝑞𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑑1𝑞q_{e}=q_{d}^{-1}\circ q (71)

As verification, note that

(s​i​n​c​e​e​r​r​o​r​q​u​a​t​e​r​n​i​o​n​t​a​k​e​s​a​v​e​c​t​o​r​f​r​o​m​b​o​d​y​f​r​a​m​e​t​o​d​e​s​i​r​e​d​f​r​a​m​e)𝑠𝑖𝑛𝑐𝑒𝑒𝑟𝑟𝑜𝑟𝑞𝑢𝑎𝑡𝑒𝑟𝑛𝑖𝑜𝑛𝑡𝑎𝑘𝑒𝑠𝑎𝑣𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑜𝑟𝑓𝑟𝑜𝑚𝑏𝑜𝑑𝑦𝑓𝑟𝑎𝑚𝑒𝑡𝑜𝑑𝑒𝑠𝑖𝑟𝑒𝑑𝑓𝑟𝑎𝑚𝑒\displaystyle(since\leavevmode\nobreak\ error\leavevmode\nobreak\ quaternion\leavevmode\nobreak\ takes\leavevmode\nobreak\ a\leavevmode\nobreak\ vector\leavevmode\nobreak\ from\leavevmode\nobreak\ body\leavevmode\nobreak\ frame\leavevmode\nobreak\ to\leavevmode\nobreak\ desired\leavevmode\nobreak\ frame) (76)

This is just one way to define the error quaternion and authors may define this quaternion in different ways.

9.1 Quaternion Error dynamics: First Order

Closed loop systems compute a feedback based not only on the error of involved quantities but also many times based on the rate of change of error. For this purpose, we derive here the expressions for quaternion error derivatives. It is to be noted that subtraction between two quantities has a meaning(or is consistent) only if they are expressed in same frame. Hence, suppose we are given a history of desired attitudes and we obtain the angular velocity from it. This operation will return us the derivative in the desired frame of references at each instant. To compare it to actual angular velocity, defined in the body frame, appropriate transformations have to be made which will be become clear below. Note that these transformations arise naturally since the physical quantities have to be consistent in their arithmetic.

From Eq.(72), we can obtain the time derivative of the error quaternion in the following way

qesubscript𝑞𝑒\displaystyle q_{e} =\displaystyle= qd−1∘qsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑑1𝑞\displaystyle q_{d}^{-1}\circ q (79)
qd∘qesubscript𝑞𝑑subscript𝑞𝑒\displaystyle q_{d}\circ q_{e} =\displaystyle= q𝑞\displaystyle q (80)
q˙d∘qe+qd​q˙esubscript˙𝑞𝑑subscript𝑞𝑒subscript𝑞𝑑subscript˙𝑞𝑒\displaystyle\dot{q}_{d}\circ q_{e}+q_{d}\dot{q}_{e} =\displaystyle= q˙˙𝑞\displaystyle\dot{q} (81)
⟹q˙eabsentsubscript˙𝑞𝑒\displaystyle\implies\dot{q}_{e} =\displaystyle= q¯d∘(q˙−q˙d∘qe)subscript¯𝑞𝑑˙𝑞subscript˙𝑞𝑑subscript𝑞𝑒\displaystyle\bar{q}_{d}\circ(\dot{q}-\dot{q}_{d}\circ q_{e}) (82)
=\displaystyle= q¯d∘(12​q∘wB−12​qd∘wdD∘qe)subscript¯𝑞𝑑12𝑞superscript𝑤𝐵12subscript𝑞𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑑𝐷subscript𝑞𝑒\displaystyle\bar{q}_{d}\circ(\frac{1}{2}q\circ w^{B}-\frac{1}{2}q_{d}\circ w_{d}^{D}\circ q_{e}) (85)

Denoting the angular velocity error as w~=wB−wdB~𝑤superscript𝑤𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑑𝐵\tilde{w}=w^{B}-w_{d}^{B}, the above equation can be written in a similar form as Eq.(35)

q˙e=12​qe∘w~subscript˙𝑞𝑒12subscript𝑞𝑒~𝑤\dot{q}_{e}=\frac{1}{2}q_{e}\circ\tilde{w} (90)

10 Quaternion to Euler Angle Conversion

Euler angles can be defined in many ways depending on the order of rotation and are still in popular use due to their simple physical interpretations. However it can be tricky to convert between quaternions and the Euler angles and this section gives a method to derive this conversion. The formula derived can be verified in a number of resources[7].

Let XYZ represent the rotation first about X axis by ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, then about new Y axis by θ𝜃\theta and finally about new Z axis by ψ𝜓\psi. Then the rotation matrix converting a vector from final frame (x,y,z) to original frame(X,Y,Z) is given by

[XYZ]matrix𝑋𝑌𝑍\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}X\\ Y\\ Z\end{bmatrix} =\displaystyle= Rϕ​Rθ​Rψ​[xyz]subscript𝑅italic-ϕsubscript𝑅𝜃subscript𝑅𝜓matrix𝑥𝑦𝑧\displaystyle R_{\phi}R_{\theta}R_{\psi}\begin{bmatrix}x\\ y\\ z\end{bmatrix} (91)
=\displaystyle= [1000cos⁡ϕ−sin⁡ϕ0sin⁡ϕcos⁡ϕ]​[cos⁡θ0sin⁡θ010−sin⁡θ0cos⁡θ]​[cos⁡ψ−sin⁡ψ0sin⁡ψcos⁡ψ0001]​[xyz]matrix1000italic-ϕitalic-ϕ0italic-ϕitalic-ϕmatrix𝜃0𝜃010𝜃0𝜃matrix𝜓𝜓0𝜓𝜓0001matrix𝑥𝑦𝑧\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}1&0&0\\ 0&\cos\phi&-\sin\phi\\ 0&\sin\phi&\cos\phi\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\cos\theta&0&\sin\theta\\ 0&1&0\\ -\sin\theta&0&\cos\theta\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\cos\psi&-\sin\psi&0\\ \sin\psi&\cos\psi&0\\ 0&0&1\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x\\ y\\ z\end{bmatrix} (92)
=\displaystyle= [cos⁡θ​cos⁡ψ−cos⁡θ​sin⁡ψsin⁡θcos⁡ϕ​sin⁡ψ+sin⁡ϕ​sin⁡θ​cos⁡ψcos⁡ϕ​cos⁡ψ−sin⁡ϕ​sin⁡θ​sin⁡ψ−sin⁡ϕ​cos⁡θsin⁡ϕ​sin⁡ψ−cos⁡ϕ​sin⁡θ​cos⁡ψsin⁡ϕ​cos⁡ψ+cos⁡ϕ​sin⁡θ​sin⁡ψcos⁡ϕ​cos⁡θ]​[xyz]matrix𝜃𝜓𝜃𝜓𝜃italic-ϕ𝜓italic-ϕ𝜃𝜓italic-ϕ𝜓italic-ϕ𝜃𝜓italic-ϕ𝜃italic-ϕ𝜓italic-ϕ𝜃𝜓italic-ϕ𝜓italic-ϕ𝜃𝜓italic-ϕ𝜃matrix𝑥𝑦𝑧\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}\cos\theta\cos\psi&-\cos\theta\sin\psi&\sin\theta\\ \cos\phi\sin\psi+\sin\phi\sin\theta\cos\psi&\cos\phi\cos\psi-\sin\phi\sin\theta\sin\psi&-\sin\phi\cos\theta\\ \sin\phi\sin\psi-\cos\phi\sin\theta\cos\psi&\sin\phi\cos\psi+\cos\phi\sin\theta\sin\psi&\cos\phi\cos\theta\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x\\ y\\ z\end{bmatrix} (93)

We have already derived the rotation matrix with quaternions which is

R=[q02+q12−q22−q322​(q1​q2−q0​q3)2​(q0​q2+q1​q3)2∗(q1​q2+q0​q3)(q02−q12+q22−q32)2​(q2​q3−q0​q1)2​(q1​q3−q0​q2)2​(q0​q1+q2​q3)q02−q12−q22+q32]𝑅matrixsuperscriptsubscript𝑞02superscriptsubscript𝑞12superscriptsubscript𝑞22superscriptsubscript𝑞322subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞32subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞32subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞3superscriptsubscript𝑞02superscriptsubscript𝑞12superscriptsubscript𝑞22superscriptsubscript𝑞322subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞3subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞12subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞3subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞22subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞3superscriptsubscript𝑞02superscriptsubscript𝑞12superscriptsubscript𝑞22superscriptsubscript𝑞32R=\begin{bmatrix}q_{0}^{2}+q_{1}^{2}-q_{2}^{2}-q_{3}^{2}&2(q_{1}q_{2}-q_{0}q_{3})&2(q_{0}q_{2}+q_{1}q_{3})\\ 2*(q_{1}q_{2}+q_{0}q_{3})&(q_{0}^{2}-q_{1}^{2}+q_{2}^{2}-q_{3}^{2})&2(q_{2}q_{3}-q_{0}q_{1})\\ 2(q_{1}q_{3}-q_{0}q_{2})&2(q_{0}q_{1}+q_{2}q_{3})&q_{0}^{2}-q_{1}^{2}-q_{2}^{2}+q_{3}^{2}\end{bmatrix} (94)

Comparing the above two matrices element by element, we can find Euler angles from the quaternions:

ϕ=tan−1⁡(−2​(q2​q3−q0​q1)q02−q12−q22+q32)italic-ϕsuperscript12subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞3subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞1superscriptsubscript𝑞02superscriptsubscript𝑞12superscriptsubscript𝑞22superscriptsubscript𝑞32\displaystyle\phi=\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-2(q_{2}q_{3}-q_{0}q_{1})}{q_{0}^{2}-q_{1}^{2}-q_{2}^{2}+q_{3}^{2}}\right) (95)
θ=sin−1⁡(2​(q0​q2+q1​q3))𝜃superscript12subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞3\displaystyle\theta=\sin^{-1}\left(2(q_{0}q_{2}+q_{1}q_{3})\right) (96)
ψ=tan−1⁡(−2​(q1​q2−q0​q3)q02+q12−q22−q32)𝜓superscript12subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2subscript𝑞0subscript𝑞3superscriptsubscript𝑞02superscriptsubscript𝑞12superscriptsubscript𝑞22superscriptsubscript𝑞32\displaystyle\psi=\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-2(q_{1}q_{2}-q_{0}q_{3})}{q_{0}^{2}+q_{1}^{2}-q_{2}^{2}-q_{3}^{2}}\right) (97)

To obtain quaternion in terms of Euler Angles, we can solve the above system of equations. However, it can be tedious to solve. Instead, we can directly construct quaternion from the knowledge of Euler sequence. For the above sequence, just like we proceeded while deriving the quaternion derivative, the local rotation is compounded to the right. We first represent the quaternions for three rotations as

qϕ=[cos⁡(ϕ2)sin⁡(ϕ2)00],qθ=[cos⁡(θ2)0sin⁡(θ2)0],qψ=[cos⁡(ψ2)00sin⁡(ψ2)]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞italic-ϕmatrixitalic-ϕ2italic-ϕ200formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝜃matrix𝜃20𝜃20subscript𝑞𝜓matrix𝜓200𝜓2q_{\phi}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\left(\frac{\phi}{2}\right)\\ \sin\left(\frac{\phi}{2}\right)\\ 0\\ 0\end{bmatrix},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ q_{\theta}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)\\ 0\\ \sin\left(\frac{\theta}{2}\right)\\ 0\end{bmatrix},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ q_{\psi}=\begin{bmatrix}\cos\left(\frac{\psi}{2}\right)\\ 0\\ 0\\ \sin\left(\frac{\psi}{2}\right)\end{bmatrix} (98)

Now compounding the rotations as before, i.e., post-multiplying the local rotations, we get

q𝑞\displaystyle q =\displaystyle= qϕ∘qθ∘qψsubscript𝑞italic-ϕsubscript𝑞𝜃subscript𝑞𝜓\displaystyle q_{\phi}\circ q_{\theta}\circ q_{\psi} (99)
=\displaystyle= [cos⁡(ϕ/2)​cos⁡(θ/2)​cos⁡(ψ/2)−sin⁡(ϕ/2)​sin⁡(θ/2)​sin⁡(ψ/2)cos⁡(ϕ/2)​sin⁡(θ/2)​sin⁡(ψ/2)+sin⁡(ϕ/2)​cos⁡(θ/2)​cos⁡(ψ/2)cos⁡(ϕ/2)​cos⁡(ψ/2)​sin⁡(θ/2)−sin⁡(ϕ/2)​cos⁡(θ/2)​sin⁡(ψ/2)cos⁡(ϕ/2)​cos⁡(θ/2)​sin⁡(ψ/2)+cos⁡(ψ/2)​sin⁡(θ/2)​sin⁡(ϕ/2)]matrixitalic-ϕ2𝜃2𝜓2italic-ϕ2𝜃2𝜓2italic-ϕ2𝜃2𝜓2italic-ϕ2𝜃2𝜓2italic-ϕ2𝜓2𝜃2italic-ϕ2𝜃2𝜓2italic-ϕ2𝜃2𝜓2𝜓2𝜃2italic-ϕ2\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}\cos(\phi/2)\cos(\theta/2)\cos(\psi/2)-\sin(\phi/2)\sin(\theta/2)\sin(\psi/2)\\ \cos(\phi/2)\sin(\theta/2)\sin(\psi/2)+\sin(\phi/2)\cos(\theta/2)\cos(\psi/2)\\ \cos(\phi/2)\cos(\psi/2)\sin(\theta/2)-\sin(\phi/2)\cos(\theta/2)\sin(\psi/2)\\ \cos(\phi/2)\cos(\theta/2)\sin(\psi/2)+\cos(\psi/2)\sin(\theta/2)\sin(\phi/2)\end{bmatrix} (100)

The above expressions can be verified with the NASA documentation[7]. The reader can also refer to this document for transformations of all 12 Euler angle combinations.

Disclaimer

These notes on quaternions are by no means complete and exhaustive. They only describe some fundamental details and do not go into much depth. They serve only to introduce the quaternions and coherently state their properties so that the reader can now readily refer to other literatures and understand the subtlety involved in the use of quaternions due to the existence of multiple conventions. Interested readers may refer to the references given below and to the vast literature accessible on Internet for greater detail.

[2]Sola, Joan. ”Quaternion kinematics for the error-state KF.” Laboratoire d’Analyse et d’Architecture des Systemes-Centre national de la recherche scientifique (LAAS-CNRS), Toulouse, France, Tech. Rep (2012)

[3]Diebel, James. ”Representing attitude: Euler angles, unit quaternions, and rotation vectors.” Matrix 58.15-16 (2006): 1-35

[4]Bhat, Sanjay P., and Dennis S. Bernstein. ”A topological obstruction to continuous global stabilization of rotational motion and the unwinding phenomenon.” Systems & Control Letters 39.1 (2000): 63-70

[5]Lee, Taeyoung, Melvin Leok, and N. Harris McClamroch. ”Control of complex maneuvers for a quadrotor UAV using geometric methods on SE (3).” arXiv preprint arXiv:1003.2005 (2010)

[6]Choset, Howie M. Principles of robot motion: theory, algorithms, and implementation. MIT press, 2005.

[7]Henderson, D. M. ”Euler angles, quaternions, and transformation matrices—Working relationships.” NASA TM-74839, JSC-12960 (1977).
